results.title: Melvin Van Peebles, Champion of New Black Cinema, Dies at 89
results.abstract: A fertile creative force, he wrote fiction and musicals but is best known for a breakthrough movie that heralded the genre known as blaxploitation.
des_facet: The Story of a Three-Day Pass (Movie)
Ain't Supposed to Die a Natural Death (Play)

multimedia.caption: The filmmaker, author and actor Melvin Van Peebles in his apartment in Manhattan in 2010. In his work he spoke out of an “undeniable Black consciousness,” one critic wrote.

results.title: Dr. Fauci, Movie Star
results.abstract: “Fauci,” a new documentary, follows his work in two health crises: AIDS and the coronavirus pandemic. He agreed to participate as long as it didn’t interfere with his work.
org_facet: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

results.title: Michael Gandolfini and the Riddle of Tony Soprano
results.abstract: In “The Many Saints of Newark,” James Gandolfini’s son takes on his father’s iconic role. But knowing his dad hardly prepared him for the work ahead.

multimedia.caption: Michael Gandolfini in New York. He pursued acting not because of his father but because he was “craving an answer” about whether he’d be good at it.

results.title: How the Cast Members of ‘Dear Evan Hansen’ Found Their Voices
results.abstract: Some stars of the movie musical, like Ben Platt and Amy Adams, were ready and eager to sing. Others, like Julianne Moore, got there eventually.

multimedia.caption: Ben Platt in “Dear Evan Hansen.” After performing the role on Broadway, where he had to be careful about reproducing the same volume night after night, he relished being able to get loud for the film.

results.title: Halle Berry’s Fight for the Director’s Chair
results.abstract: In many ways, her new film “Bruised” lets her assert control over how she appears onscreen. But first she had to win the job.

results.title: Andrew Garfield Can’t Remember Who He Was Before ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’
results.abstract: In the movie musical, Garfield plays the creator of “Rent,” who died unexpectedly at 35. Making the film helped Garfield process a death in his own life.

multimedia.caption: “Tick, Tick … Boom” is about Jonathan Larson, who created “Rent.” To Andrew Garfield, “every frame, every moment, every breath of this film is an attempted honoring of Jon. And, on a more personal level, it’s an honoring of my mom.”
multimedia.copyright: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “Tick, Tick … Boom” is about Jonathan Larson, who created “Rent.” To Andrew Garfield, “every frame, every moment, every breath of this film is an attempted honoring of Jon. And, on a more personal level, it’s an honoring of my mom.”

results.title: Our Film Critics Discuss the Future of Movies
results.abstract: Taking a look at the new season in the new abnormal, while remembering the lessons of cinema history. Are we on the cusp of a new era or will this too pass?
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott

results.title: The Rich History of Black Westerns Enters a New Era
results.abstract: The genre dates back decades, when the films were made for segregated audiences. “The Harder They Fall” nods to the past but takes a new attitude altogether.

results.title: ‘The Most Beautiful Boy in the World’ Review: A Cautionary Tale
results.abstract: The 1971 film “Death in Venice” showcased the delicate androgyny of Bjorn Andresen’s face and form, but the changes it wrought on his life are indelible.

results.title: Saadi Yacef, ‘Battle of Algiers’ Catalyst and Actor, Dies at 93
results.abstract: At the center of the Algerian effort to throw off French rule, he re-created that role in Gillo Pontecorvo’s searing 1966 movie, based on a book by Mr. Yacef.

multimedia.caption: Saadi Yacef, second from left, in a scene from “The Battle of Algiers,” a movie by Gillo Pontecorvo about the war between Algerian independence fighters and France. Mr. Yacef had fought in the war, and his writings were the basis for the movie.

Saadi Yacef, second from left, in a scene from “The Battle of Algiers,” a movie by Gillo Pontecorvo about the war between Algerian independence fighters and France. Mr. Yacef had fought in the war, and his writings were the basis for the movie.

results.title: Lena Waithe, Gillian Flynn to Start Book Imprints
results.abstract: The two women are joining Zando, an independent publishing company founded last year that plans to work with authors and sell books in unconventional ways.

multimedia.caption: “I’m hoping we can have a force multiplier effect on books that would have sold modestly or wouldn’t have been a priority at a large publishing house,” said Molly Stern, Zando’s founder. “Now there will be air around them.”
multimedia.copyright: Gabriela Herman for The New York Times

results.title: Anthony Johnson, Actor Known for ‘Friday,’ Dies at 55
